Author: Lukrativ_

Comment: Also probably worth noting that it's a minimum 2.45x on price. Often companies price based on margins, which would add even more to that. A $10 cost landed item that they need to keep a 50% margin on would cost $20 on Amazon's site. If they try to keep margin with the new tariffs, then the cost landed becomes $24.50, putting the new margin price at $49, not just $20 + $14.50 in tariffs. It's often not just a simple "add the tariff, and that's the cost", it's a working capital calculation. It's currently what's devastating the board game industry, sadly.   And to note, not all companies will do that, some will eat some of the tariff, some will pass the tariff on and sacrifice margin, but a good amount just need to keep the margin to survive. Many companies can't have a huge capital outlay (cost to manufacture + tariff) to make the same amount. If they are borrowing that capital, then their margins get eaten up even faster by debt servicing. It's crushing to everyone involved.

It's often because if they answer they'll be committing perjury (by lying), revealing perjury (by being honest but contradicting something else they said), or leaving themselves open for being caught in perjury (if they want to say something that contradicts the truth later). So they usually go with one or both of those.
